p:
The estimated asymptotic growth rates from the destination-mediated-dispersal and source-mediated-dispersal models did not respond to spatial distribution of the dispersal vectors (Fig. 3, gray triangles and red squares). These estimated values did not differ from the growth rate at
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$F_{{\text{h}}} = 1$$\end{document}
F h
= 1
(i.e., the asymptotic growth rate of the spatially homogeneous model). On the other hand, in the full models, large values of the spatial factors resulted in large values of estimated asymptotic growth rates (i.e., faster population growth after the initial introduction) (Fig. 3, blue circles). These estimated values correspond well with the theoretical expectations from Eq. ( 4) (Fig. 3, solid lines).
